awd_titl_txt: From Single Ion to Correlation: Probing the Physics of Kondo Topological Insulator with Lattice Constant Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract: 

Wonder what happens to the electronic properties of a material when you stretch it? In an electronic material, the valence of an atom tells us the strength of its combining power with other atoms, and does not usually change with time. In some very special materials, called 'mixed valence compounds', the valence rapidly fluctuates between more than one value. It is recently discovered by the principle investigator that stretching some of these mixed valence compounds could slow down or speed up the valence fluctuation. As a result, the electronic properties are effectively tuned to meet the requirements of device applications. In this project, the research team investigates the effect of stretching on mixed valence in several so-called 'strongly correlated materials'. Cousins of these materials have already found technological importance: high temperature superconductors for MRI diagnosis, giant magneto-resistance materials inside iPads, just to name two. This project pursues crystal growth, measurements and device fabrication on several mixed valence materials to unveil the nature of mixed valence physics and by extension explore their unusual electronic and thermal properties for technological applications such as ultra-high frequency oscillator and quantum metrology. Several educational components are integrated into this project, consisting of course development, K-12 outreach and scientific training for students. Internships for high school volunteers from disadvantaged regions in Santa Ana, as well as undergraduate researcher from UC Irvine's California Alliance for Minority Participation program are enabled by this project to generate interest and prepare for careers in science and technology.

Technical Abstract

     The normally well localized and magnetic 4f-electrons in rare earth compounds can in some materials become itinerant electrons with effective electron mass orders of magnitude larger than that of free electrons, leading variously to unusual 'strongly correlated' superconducting, magnetic and semiconducting states, these last known as Kondo insulators. Theory suggests that the Kondo insulator SmB6 belongs to the exotic class of so-called topological insulators possessing a surface conducting state with interesting technological potential. SmB6 is at present the only such strongly correlated f-band semiconductor for which experiment finds good evidence for this. The semiconducting energy gap scale in SmB6 is approximately 40K with the surface conducting state developing only below 4K. The principal investigators find that uniaxial strain strongly increases the gap energy and moves the development of the surface conducting state to 200K, approaching a range useful for application.
     The goals of this project are to discover what sets the energy gap scale and accompanying development of the surface state, how this scale can be controlled and where other strongly correlated topological insulators can be found. This will be pursued in single crystal alloys of SmB6 and other Kondo insulators via transport, magnetic and thermodynamic measurements at ambient pressure and under strain. There is no reason to suppose that SmB6 is a unique material and understanding what sets the energy gap scale can present the rationale for discovery of other strongly correlated semiconductors in its exotic class with potential for application.

por.por_cntn:
SmB6 is a topological Kondo Insulator. While the nature of its topological surface state remains to be fully understood, the physics of its mixed-valence state could lead to attractive electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties that can be controlled via strain engineering. Exploiting its nonlinear dynamics, we have recently fabricated a micron-sized tunable SmB6 RF oscillator device, Phys. Rev. Lett. 116(16), 166603, (2016). In the experiment shown in Figure 1, we show direct measurements of the time-dependent surface-state temperature in SmB6 with a micro-thermometer ("Direct observation of surface-state thermal oscillations in SmB6 oscillators", Phys. Rev. B 97, 035121 (2018)). Our results agree quantitatively with the theoretically simulated temperature waveform, and hence support the validity of the oscillator model, which will provide accurate theoretical guidance for developing future SmB6 oscillators at higher frequencies and will further our understanding of the nature of this puzzling mixed-valence strongly correlated material. 

To elucidate the nature of the reported quantum oscillation in SmB6, we have performed torque magnetization measurements to detect de Haas van Alphen (dHvA) oscillations in SmB6 crystals grown by aluminum flux. We find that dHvA oscillations occur in single crystals containing embedded aluminum, originating from the flux used to synthesize SmB6. Measurements on a sample with multiple, unconnected aluminum inclusions in Figure 2 show that aluminum crystallizes in a preferred orientation within the SmB6 cubic lattice. The presence of aluminum is confirmed through bulk susceptibility measurements but does not show a signature in transport measurements as shown in Figure 2. We have discussed the ramifications of our results ("Quantum Oscillations in Flux-Grown SmB6 with Embedded Aluminum". Physical Review Letters 122, 166401 (2019)).

A collaboration with the STM group of Steffen Wirth at the Max Planck Institute of Chemical Physics of Solids in Dresden has studied the effect of magnetic and non-magnetic substitutions of the low-temperature surface state in SmB6 (Science Advances 4, 4886 (2018)). It is found that the surface state is suppressed around magnetic substitutions more rapidly than around non-magnetic substitutions as shown in Fig.3. The effect of the local magnetic field on the surface state was further studied using an STM tip that had picked up a magnetic Gd atom. This tip also locally suppressed the surface state features in the tunneling spectra. This experiment provides further direct evidence for the topological nature of semiconducting SmB6. Interestingly, non-magnetic defects in SmB6 disrupt the surface state within a radius of approximately 1 nm, corresponding to a distance of two units cells, and indicating that a percolation path via defects should exist already for low defect concentrations.

We have also collaborated with Eo and Kurdak at the University of Michigan in a detailed study of the temperature dependencies of the surface and bulk electrical conductivities of SmB6 (Physical Review Applied 9, 044006 (2018)). At low temperatures, the conducting surface state shorts out the bulk contribution, while at temperatures above 10K the bulk conductivity dominates. Two different variants of a Corbino-type geometry are used in these two regions using a so-called inverted resistance measurement, these geometries are shown in Figure 4. These two particular geometries are sensitive in the opposite regimes of surface-dominated and bulk-dominated conductivities. Numerical calculations allow the extraction of separate conductivities. The measurements on SmB6 Al-flux grown single crystals find several remarkable results. The bulk conductivity is that of a perfect semiconductor with a gap of 4 meV. Between 300K and 2K, the bulk resistivity rises ten orders of magnitude. Measurements on off-stoichiometric crystals have the same gap value, the rise in resistivity being less than the ten orders of magnitude. What this finding seems to indicate is that there are no in-gap states in this putative topological insulator, that the gap appears to be protected.
